ehycptn.Author: tommygunz007
ehycptn.Text:
Just so I understand, Starbucks has to pay it's rent and bills in fiat, so it is going to use an intermediary to take payments as an exchange. Exchanges rely on fees, so basically, a $5 latte is (for argument's sake) 5btc PLUS some kind of fee which protects starbucks from an instantaneous crash. Like, I buy a 5 btc latte and a second later, it either booms or busts. Starbucks needs some kind of insurance, or instantaneous exchange. Insurance would be a fee of 3%, or instantaneous exchange to fiat would also be a fee added. 

The hurdle isn't that people won't accept bitcoin, it's that it's not native to how they pay their rent. If their rent is 10,000 a month in fiat, and the cost of bitcoin fluctuates, it could really burn their bottom line if they don't immediately exchange it, so a $5 latte will cost the consumer 5 btc + the fee. (assuming it's 1-1)

ehyfn80.Author: cryptogrip
ehyfn80.Text:
I'm not sure where you got the info, but Starbucks have an equity deal with Bakkt, which will function as a cryptocurrency payments platform.
Purchases will be made in-store using special software from Bakkt. This all about progress in extremely early days. These types of partnerships and developments help moving forward with applications for customers to convert their digital assets into US dollars, which can then be used in stores. The exchange you're talking about in your post...would be Bakkt.

ehykx89.Author: tommygunz007
ehykx89.Text: Right, so basically, Bakkt would be the vendor payment processor. You pay Bakkt, they take a 3% fee, convert immediately to fiat, and deposit it into the starbucks account. Otherwise, if they sit on the Bitcoin, that $5 latte suddenly becomes a $3 latte as Bitcoin price changes.

ehxdcqx.Author: live9free1or1die
ehxdcqx.Text: Based on what a CPA had told me cryptocurrencies are filed as assets, therefore using either LIFO or FIFO does obviously apply here. Whether LIFO or FIFO is your choice as a client/tax payer. I would just get a 2nd opinion or force yourself to learn the ins and outs and file yourself.

ehyy3op.Author: cryptogrip
ehyy3op.Text: I'm sure Starbucks won't pay a typical fee to Bakkt, because as mentioned, it's a partnership. Whatever amount of bitcoin is worth the dollar amount of the purchase at that moment in time would be exchanged by the software. There's nothing to analyze here, it's pretty simple. Bakkt will be dealing in bitcoin so they are promoting their agenda, and Starbucks get additional publicity as they become early participants in a shift toward cryptocurrencies.

ehxlwdu.Text: As someone who has witnessed the stock market’s longest bull run in history, 10th birthday on Saturday, I think the healthiest thing for bitcoin to do is work its way slowly turning one resistance level into support over time.
